title.value: Effective Latent Differential Equation Models via Attention and Multiple Shooting
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as stated in the provided text.
title.quote: Effective Latent Differential Equation Models via Attention and Multiple Shooting

extractions.description: This paper introduces GOKU-UI, an evolution of the Scientific Machine Learning (SciML) generative model GOKU-nets. GOKU-UI has enhanced capabilities like integrating other classes of differential equations, including Stochastic Differential Equations (SDEs), attention mechanisms, and a multiple shooting training strategy in the latent space. These modifications are shown to significantly improve the model's performance in both reconstruction and forecast tasks for synthetic and empirical data, particularly in capturing complex brain dynamics.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments on simulated and empirical datasets to evaluate the performance of the proposed GOKU-UI model, showing empirical results and comparisons.
type.quote: Our experiments indicated that non-variational GOKU-nets models outperform their variational counterparts significantly (see Supplementary Information C). Therefore, we used non-variational GOKU-nets for all the remaining results in this work. Specifically, instead of sampling from normal distributions in the latent space as shown in Figure 1, we directly take the mean values µz and µθ .

name.justification: The paper focuses on enhancing a deep learning model (GOKU-UI) for better performance in tasks such as reconstruction and forecasting by integrating deep learning techniques like attention mechanisms.
name.quote: By training GOKU-UI on resting state fMRI data, we encoded whole-brain dynamics into a latent representation, learning a low-dimensional dynamical system model that could offer insights into brain functionality and open avenues for practical applications such as the classification of mental states or psychiatric conditions.

name.justification: The primary focus is on Scientific Machine Learning (SciML), combining domain-specific knowledge with machine learning techniques to solve complex problems in STEM fields.
name.quote: Scientific Machine Learning (SciML) is a burgeoning field that synergistically combines domain-aware and interpretable models with agnostic machine learning techniques. In this work, we introduce GOKU-UI, an evolution of the SciML generative model GOKU-nets.

name.justification: GOKU-UI is introduced and discussed extensively as the main contribution of the paper.
name.quote: In this work, we introduce GOKU-UI, an evolution of the SciML generative model GOKU-nets. GOKU-UI not only broadens the original model’s spectrum to incorporate other classes of differential equations, such as Stochastic Differential Equations (SDEs), but also integrates attention mechanisms and a novel multiple shooting training strategy in the latent space.

name.justification: This synthetic dataset is used for evaluating the proposed model, particularly in the synthetic data experiments section.
name.quote: We have evaluated our enhanced model and training strategy on simulated data from a network of stochastic oscillators, specifically Stuart-Landau oscillators.

name.justification: Resting state fMRI data from the Track-On HD study is used for empirical evaluations of the model.
name.quote: We used the resting state fMRI data from 153 subjects, sourced from the Track-On HD study (Klöppel et al., 2015).

name.justification: This Julia library is employed for solving differential equations in the study.
name.quote: For each set of parameters and initial conditions, the system is integrated with the SOSRI solver, a Stability-optimized adaptive strong order 1.5 and weak order 2.0 for diagonal/scalar Ito SDEs, from the DifferentialEquations.jl Julia package (Rackauckas & Nie, 2017).

name.justification: The library ModelingToolkit.jl is used to define differential equations for better computational performance.
name.quote: The differential equations definitions were optimized for higher computational performance with the help of ModelingToolkit.jl (Ma et al., 2021c).

name.justification: The deep learning model was defined and trained within the Flux.jl package.
name.quote: The models were defined and trained within the deep learning framework of the Flux.jl package (Innes et al., 2018).

name.justification: The sensitivity algorithm was used from this package during training.
name.quote: The sensitivity algorithm used was ForwardDiffSensitivity from the SciMLSensitivity.jl package (Rackauckas et al., 2020).

name.justification: The experiments were managed using this package.
name.quote: The experiments were managed using DrWatson.jl package (Datseris et al., 2020).
